awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: OLC SDSU SDSMT PreEngineering Education Collaborative - Phase II
awd_abstract_narration:
A goal of the Tribal Colleges and Universities Program (TCUP) is to increase the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) instructional and research capacities of specific institutions of higher education that serve the Nation's indigenous students. The PEEC-II track provides support for studies or educational research conducted by institutions that have had earlier Pre-Engineering Education Collaborative (PEEC) awards.  The intent of PEEC-II is to capture, analyze, and disseminate the impact of these awards on the participating institutions, faculty, or students, and their communities. PEEC and PEEC-II are partnerships between TCUP and the Directorate for Engineering.

During PEEC-I, Oglala Lakota College (OLC) in conjunction with collaborators the College of Engineering at the South Dakota State University (SDSU) and the South Dakota School of Mines and Technology (SDSMT), referred to as OLC/SDSU/SDSMT PEEC (OSSPEEC), established infrastructure and capacity for students entering OLC to graduate from SDSU or SDSMT with engineering degrees.  In PEEC-II, they will investigate the impact of the OSSPEEC model, which emphasizes the importance of experiential learning, incorporation of the Lakota world view and cultural perspective in engineering learning and decision making, and development of self-confidence in solving engineering problems.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in understanding the value of the OSSPEEC model and what factors lead to American Indian success in pre-engineering and engineering programs.  The integrated research and experiential learning aspects of the project have the potential to generate knowledge related to water resources and geological engineering on the Pine Ridge Reservation in South Dakota.  The broader impacts of this project will be 1) increased diversity in a globally engaged engineering workforce, 2) expanded tribal ability to address issues related to land use, drinking water, and sustainable housing and food production, and 3) a model of culturally centered classroom activities and relevant co-curricular research, project and maker activities.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
With the goal of strengthening the ability of Tribal Colleges to deliver pre-engineering and engineering curriculum, the National Science Foundation funded what became known as the PEEC (Pre-Engineering Education Collaborative) program. The program was continued under PEEC-II. In previous years of the award, South Dakota State University (SDSU) collaborated with Oglala Lakota College (OLC) and South Dakota School of Mines and Technology (SDSMT) to increase capacity at OLC, where they offer a pre-engineering program based on constructivist teaching principles and design throughout the curriculum. This approach was unique in aligning engineering education with community-relevant (Tribal and Native Hawaiian), hands-on projects as a vehicle for students to better understand engineering activities and principles. Through the PEEC program, SDSU was able to support students earning bachelor?s and master?s degrees in engineering or STEM fields, support the American Indian Science and Engineering Society (AISES) SDSU chapter, and facilitate regional cooperation and support among AISES chapters. In a mutually beneficial arrangement, SDSU PEEC students conducted projects of importance to the Greater Pine Ridge Reservation (GPRR) community. Students presented results of their research at various regional and national meetings, as well as by co-authoring publications.

 

A broader impact of this work was that culturally relevant, hands-on activities positively impacted the preparation and persistence of pre-engineering and engineering students, especially those who are under-represented in STEM. Other broader impacts of PEEC are reflected in the number of Native Americans in PEEC who performed research, earned undergraduate and advanced degrees, wrote and published papers, and who continue to inspire others to follow in their footsteps, as well as K-12 teacher training at multiple tribal colleges and school districts. At SDSU in particular, there is now unprecedented interest in outreach and in bringing Native American students to campus through the leadership of our president, Dr. Barry Dunn, who set the goal of increasing Native American enrollment from 250 to 1,000 students. In support of this, a new, 12,400 square foot American Indian Student Center was built on campus in 2020. The SDSU PEEC are eager to welcome as many of the new students as possible to the Jerome J. Lohr College of Engineering at SDSU based on what we have learned from being a part of PEEC and PEEC-II.

 


Last Modified: 09/09/2021
Modified by: Suzette R Burckhard

por.por_txt_cntn:
With the goal of strengthening the ability of Tribal Colleges to deliver pre-engineering and engineering curriculum, the National Science Foundation funded what became known as the PEEC (Pre-Engineering Education Collaborative) program. The program was continued under PEEC-II. In previous years of the award, South Dakota State University (SDSU) collaborated with Oglala Lakota College (OLC) and South Dakota School of Mines and Technology (SDSMT) to increase capacity at OLC, where they offer a pre-engineering program based on constructivist teaching principles and design throughout the curriculum. This approach was unique in aligning engineering education with community-relevant (Tribal and Native Hawaiian), hands-on projects as a vehicle for students to better understand engineering activities and principles. Through the PEEC program, SDSU was able to support students earning bachelor?s and master?s degrees in engineering or STEM fields, support the American Indian Science and Engineering Society (AISES) SDSU chapter, and facilitate regional cooperation and support among AISES chapters. In a mutually beneficial arrangement, SDSU PEEC students conducted projects of importance to the Greater Pine Ridge Reservation (GPRR) community. Students presented results of their research at various regional and national meetings, as well as by co-authoring publications.

 

A broader impact of this work was that culturally relevant, hands-on activities positively impacted the preparation and persistence of pre-engineering and engineering students, especially those who are under-represented in STEM. Other broader impacts of PEEC are reflected in the number of Native Americans in PEEC who performed research, earned undergraduate and advanced degrees, wrote and published papers, and who continue to inspire others to follow in their footsteps, as well as K-12 teacher training at multiple tribal colleges and school districts. At SDSU in particular, there is now unprecedented interest in outreach and in bringing Native American students to campus through the leadership of our president, Dr. Barry Dunn, who set the goal of increasing Native American enrollment from 250 to 1,000 students. In support of this, a new, 12,400 square foot American Indian Student Center was built on campus in 2020. The SDSU PEEC are eager to welcome as many of the new students as possible to the Jerome J. Lohr College of Engineering at SDSU based on what we have learned from being a part of PEEC and PEEC-II.
